abstracts.cdata!:
The recommendation with respect to
            development credits for Ethiopia, which is the principal
            reason for the meeting this morning. The education credit is
            the second credit to Ethiopia and, together with the highway
            credit of 1963, will increase our total commitment to about
            $21 million as compared with total Bank loans of about $57
            million. In the past Bank financing has been repeatedly
            channeled into highway construction and telecommunications,
            with a small amount to the Development Bank of Ethiopia. The
            present education project and the prospective agricultural
            credit project and a water and sewage project for the city
            of Addis Ababa will certainly be welcome additions to the
            areas with which we have been associated with in the past
            and most likely will continue to be associated in the
            future. Bank pointed out that Ethiopia's performance in
            certain sector such as exports, transport and power, has
            been satisfactory. Perhaps most important, in the long run,
            are arrangements presently under negotiation with AID for an
            agro industrial survey for identification and preparation of
            projects. These are some of the indications that greater
            efforts are being made by the Ethiopian and outside agencies
            in the preparation of projects that might lead to higher
            levels of investment in the near future.
